N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 9 ยง 6653.7 - Area plan amendments

State Regulations
(a) An area agency must amend its area plan
if: (1)
a new or amended State or Federal
statute or regulation requires a new provision, or conflicts with any existing
plan provision; (2)
a United States

Supreme Court or New York State Court of Appeals decision changes the
interpretation of a statute or regulation so that it conflicts with any
existing area plan provision; (3)
the area agency proposes to assume a new purpose or to change the structure or
designation of a single organizational unit or component unit pursuant to this

Chapter. The area agency must document the following when making a request in a
plan or plan amendment to deviate from being a single-purpose agency serving
only the elderly: (i) documents in its
request the involvement of its advisory council in the proposed reorganization
and of opportunity for the public to review and comment that the public has
been provided the opportunity to review and comment on the requested
reorganization; (ii)
describes its
methods for carrying out its functions and responsibilities under title III of
the Older Americans Act; and
(iii)
(iii)
(a) proposes an area agency on aging which has, as its primary and major
responsibility, the carrying out of Older Americans Act mandates, but which
also administers a program(s) which serve other populations, provided such an
arrangement increases area agency on aging visibility and viability, improves
access to services by the elderly and enhances and improves the status of the
elderly; or
(b) proposes a single
organizational unit within a multi-purpose agency with the visibility, authority and capacity to assume total responsibility for carrying out the
mandates of the Older Americans Act; (4)
the area agency proposes to add, substantially modify, or delete any area plan objective, service, CSE project
or EISEP service; or
(5)
the office
requires an amendment. (b) Proposed area plan amendments shall be
submitted for approval to the office under the same procedures as initial area
plans. Notes
